title: Isaac Newton
text: Formulated the laws of motion and universal gravitation, laying the foundation for classical mechanics.

title: Albert Einstein
text: Developed the theory of relativity and made significant contributions to quantum mechanics.

title: Charles Darwin
text: Proposed the theory of evolution through natural selection, fundamentally changing our understanding of biology.

title: Galileo Galilei
text: Made significant contributions to astronomy and physics, including improvements to the telescope and early astronomical observations.

title: Jesus Christ
text: Central figure of Christianity, believed to be the Son of God and savior of humanity.

title: Muhammad
text: Founder of Islam and regarded as the last prophet in Islamic tradition.

title: Leonardo da Vinci
text: Renowned polymath of the Renaissance, known for his contributions to art, science, and engineering.

title: Marie Curie
text: Pioneered research on radioactivity, becoming the first woman to win a Nobel Prize and the only person to win Nobel Prizes in two different scientific fields.

title: Julius Caesar
text: Roman general and statesman who played a critical role in the events that  led to the demise of the Roman Republic and the rise of the Roman Empire.

title: Kleopatra VII
text: The last active ruler of the Ptolemaic Kingdom of Egypt, known for her intelligence, political acumen, and relationships with Roman leaders Julius Caesar and Mark Antony.

title: Alexander the Great
text: King of Macedonia who created one of the largest empires in ancient history, spreading Greek culture throughout the known world.

title: Socrates
text: Classical Greek philosopher credited as one of the founders of Western philosophy, known for his contributions to ethics and epistemology.

title: Christopher Columbus
text: Italian explorer who completed four voyages across the Atlantic Ocean, opening the way for the widespread European exploration and colonization of the Americas.

title: Genghis Khan
text: Founder and first Great Khan of the Mongol Empire, which became the largest contiguous empire in history after his death.

title: Marthin Luther
text: German professor of theology, composer, priest, monk, and a seminal figure in the Protestant Reformation.
